history.content: Do you have any suggestions, @John DeNero  ?

children.subject:
Hi Professor DeNero,

I saw on the draft schedule that you'll be co-teaching CS288 in Spring 2018. 

I'm trying to plan ahead a little, and so I wanted to ask: I know CS188 is listed as a pre-requisite, but do you think CS189 is equally necessary or useful as a foundation for 288?

Thank you!

Good question. I would normally recommend Michael Collins' Coursera course, but it appears to be offline. He still has notes up here, but I was unable to access the videos:

http://www.cs.columbia.edu/~cs4705/

Prof. David Bamman will teach an undergraduate course on NLP in Fall 2017. The course number will be Info 159/259. I'd recommend taking that! I expect that a machine learning course such as 189 would be useful as a prerequisite.

Yes, there's a chance. We're aware that there is a lot of demand. 

However, CS 288 is a graduate course. Historically, very few undergraduates have chosen to stay in the course beyond the first two weeks. And of course, graduate students will have enrollment priority for the course if it is offered.
Is there any possibility that some instructor will be teaching CS 288 in spring 2018? I believe it's a rapidly growing field that more students wanna take this class these two years.

history.content:
The old Coursera videos for Michael Collins' class can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/user/afigfigueira/playlists?sort=dd&view=50&shelf_id=5

There's also an old Coursera class by Jurafsky and Manning at Stanford: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6397E4B26D00A269

Finally, if you're interested in more advanced NLP, I'd recommend the Deep Learning for NLP class taught by Richard Socher at Stanford: http://web.stanford.edu/class/cs224n/

The old Coursera videos for Michael Collins' class can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/user/afigfigueira/playlists?sort=dd&view=50&shelf_id=5

There's also an old Coursera class by Jurafsky and Manning at Stanford: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6397E4B26D00A269

Finally, if you're interested in more advanced NLP, I'd recommend the NLP for deep learning class taught by Richard Socher at Stanford: http://web.stanford.edu/class/cs224n/

children.subject: If you are concerned about your preparation for the course, please contact the instructor directly. It's a new course, so only he can answer that question. dbamman@berkeley.edu
Does Info 159 need Stat 134 and Math 55 as hard prereqs?

A linguistics course in natural language syntax or morphology would be useful. A linguistic typology course would also be great. I'm not sure what the course numbers are at Berkeley. 

For math and stat, I'd recommend numerical optimization (e.g. EE 127) , linear algebra, and stochastic processes (e.g., EE 126).

Taking more linguistics and philosophy is interesting and fun, but perhaps not directly related to your career.

Morphology (and phonology) is Ling115, while syntax (and semantics) is Ling120. Ling115 has a reasonably important prereq of Ling100, although Ling5 would probably be sufficient as well. Ling120 is probably manageable without the prereq, although I'm not sure how much the course varies based on professor.

Typology would be Ling122, but that course assumes a reasonable linguistics background (e.g. 110 (phonetics) and others); I was enrolled in it for a few weeks, but had to drop it because I couldn't follow along, having not taken 110 yet.

Jumping on this thread a little late.

I am considering a career in NLP, and will be taking Info 159 with professor Bamman and Statistics 135 next semester, but have some space open for electives or other technicals. Professor DeNero, what kinds of courses would you recommend for a career in NLP (in addition to 188/189)? How useful are courses in linguistics and philosophy? What math and statistics topics are useful?

I suppose I should also clarify that I am unsure of whether I'd like to pursue a career in academia or industry just yet, so I'd like to take a sequence of courses that prepares me for both. I appreciate your suggestions.

history.content:
Seeing as CS 288 might not be offered soon, I'm wondering what is the best way for me, as a CS student, to learn NLP. My thinking was that I should learn (1) probability and statistics, (2) algorithms, (3) machine learning, and (3) syntax and semantics here at Berkeley. I finish phases 1 and 2 this semester (though not deeply).

Then, when I have time, I can read a NLP book like "Foundations of Statistical Natural Language Processing" and understand how these concepts are applied to NLP.

Is this the best way to go? Another idea is to self-study past CS 288 materials. Prof. Sahai mentioned in a earlier thread that Professors have insight into learning students don't, and he is absolutely correct. We have Prof. Denero, among others, on this Piazza, who are NLP experts.

Also, just to be clear, I'm not focused on NLP as my career. I feel that it's a supremely useful area of CS to know, though. Thank you!
history.subject: How to best learn Natural Language Processing on my own?
